pages.text: Waagenella jonesianus is a substantially large species of Bellerophontida, a group commonly accepted to represent an order of primitive sea snails. First discovered in 1863 by Belgian paleontologist Laurent-Guillaume de Koninck. It is notably found from India and Akasaka Limestone of Japan. Waagenella jonesianus has had a very messy history of taxonomic classification. It is occasionally and was initially classed within the genus of Bellerophon, a wastebasket grouping. It is notable for it's large size which can reach up to 18 cm. Many Bellerophontida have a "waterline" about halfway up the shell, suggesting that the mantle likely covered a large portion of the shell in life such as is present in modern Naticids.
